prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High Resolution 345 GHz Dust Continuum and Spectral Line Maps of Class I Protostars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map Class I protostar disks in 345 GHz continuum and HCN, H13CN and HC15N at high spatial and spectral resolution to determine their structure and masses, measure Keplerian rotation, and map dust grain growth spatially in the disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have produced synthetic channel maps for HCN (4-3) and H13CN (4-3) and HC15N (4-3) for a selection of protostar models using our radiative transfer infrastructure and gas abudances from Aikawa et al. (2005). Expected peak brightnesses for these disks range from >500 mJy/beam for HCN (4-3), >100 mJy/beam for H13CN (4-3), and >50 mJy/beam for HC15N (4-3) in 0.1 km/s channels, needed to spectrally resolve Keplerian rotation, and an 0.1" beam. We therefore request a sensitivity of 50 mJy in 0.1 km/s channels to make sure we at least detect HCN (4-3) with S/N ~ 10. Peak brightnesses for each line can increase significantly, so our requested sensitivity will likely allow us to detect H13CN (4-3) and HC15N (4-3) as well.
Our targets have been previously observed at 1mm with a 1" beam (Eisner 2012) or with an 11" beam (Motte & Andre 2001). To estimate the flux per resolution element, of ~0.1" for the proposed extended configuration observations, we assume that previously measured millimeter fluxes for our targets trace an optically thin, face-on disk with a surface density profile Sigma ~ r^-1 and a temperature profile T ~ r^-0.5. We use that F_nu ~ nu^(2+beta) at millimeter wavelengths, with a reasonable assumption of beta=0.7 (e.g. Rodmann et al. 2006, Ricci et al. 2010a,b), to estimate the 870 micron fluxes. We find that our targets will have peak brightnesses of 9-130 mJy/beam in a 0.1" beam. We will devote two of our basebands to wideband continuum observations, so we use a bandwidth of 3.75 GHz when calculating the exposure time required to achieve the requested sensitivity. To map the disk we must detect extended emission, which can be >10 times fainter than the peak brightness, at S/N > 2. We therefore request time on each source to achieve a peak S/N of 20. The time required from spectral line constraints, however, is larger than the time required by the continuum constraints, so we opt to request for the time required by the spectral line observations.

We will devote two of our basebands to continuum observations and two basebands to spectral line observations. We have produced synthetic channel maps for HCO+ (3-2) and HCN (3-2) based on the best fit protostar models for GV Tau N & S from Sheehan & Eisner 2014 using our radiative transfer infrastructure and gas abudances from Aikawa et al. (2005). We find that linewidths for HCN (3-2) and HCO+ (3-2) for these models are >2 km/s and that 0.13 km/s channels will well resolve the Keplerian rotation in the disk (see Figure 2). These values are in good agreement with measurements for similar spectral line observations of Class I protostars (e.g. Jorgensen et al. 2009). We therefore request 0.13 km/s channels for these observations.

Our observations have been designed to detect, at high spatial and spectral resolution, dust continuum and spectral line emission from protoplanetary disks. The parameters chosen have been previously justified and the high data rate is a product of those parameters.

The primary goal of our 345 GHz observations is to resolve the compact disks, and more importantly the planet forming regions in those disks, around Class I protostars in both continuum and spectral lines. Planets are expected to form within a radius of ~50 AU, or a 0.6" diameter at 140 pc, so we therefore request a resolution of ~0.1". The high resolution is essential for resolving the Class I disks, and in particular the regions in those disks where planets are forming. It is not essential for our 345 GHz observations to remain sensitive to large scale structure from the envelope as that will be accomplished by our 100 GHz observations. Protoplanetary disk radii are expected to be on the order of 300 AU, or a diameter of 4.5" at 140 pc, so we use 4.5" as the largest angular scale for our targets. We do not require the ACA for our 345 GHz observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High Resolution 100 GHz Dust Continuum Maps of the Planet Forming Regions in Class I Protostar Disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the compact disks, and planet forming regions within those disks, which exist around Class I protostars in 100 GHz dust continuum at high resolution to determine their structure and masses.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our targets have been previously observed at 1mm with a 1" beam (Eisner 2012) or with an 11" beam (Motte & Andre 2001). To estimate the flux per resolution element, of ~0.1" for the proposed extended configuration observations, we assume that previously measured millimeter fluxes for our targets trace an optically thin, face-on disk with a surface density profile Sigma ~ r^-1 and a temperature profile T ~ r^-0.5. We use that F_nu ~ nu^(2+beta) at millimeter wavelengths, with a reasonable assumption of beta=0.7 (e.g. Rodmann et al. 2006, Ricci et al. 2010a,b), to estimate the 3 mm fluxes for targets without previous 3mm observations. We find that our targets will have peak brightnesses of 0.6-4.7 mJy/beam in a 0.1" beam. We will devote all four of our basebands to continuum observations, so we use 7.5 GHz of bandwidth to calculate sensitivity. Here we map only the bright inner regions of the disk, so we request a sensitivity such that our observations will have S/N ~ 10.
Our observations in this band are continuum observations, so we request the default configuration for Band 3 continuum observations.

We request high spatial resolution so that we can well resolve the compact disks, and more importantly the planet forming regions in those disks, around Class I protostars. Planets are expected to form within a radius of ~50 AU, or a 0.6" diameter at 140 pc, so the requested resolution, of ~0.1" is essential for resolving these regions. The maximum recoverable scale for an ALMA configuration delivering 0.1" resolution at 3 mm is ~1.5", or 210 AU at 140 pc. This is more than enough to resolve the compact scales in protoplanetary disks where planets form, so we use 1.5" as the largest angular scale. We propose in another Science Goal to study larger scale structure from the disk and envelope.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Low Resolution 100 GHz Dust Continuum Maps of Class I Protostar Disks and Their Natal Envelopes
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map Class I protostellar disks and their natal envelopes in 100 GHz dust continuum at a range of spatial scales which remain sensitive to both the compact disks and large scale structure from the envelope.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our targets have been previously observed at 1mm with a 1" beam (Eisner 2012) or with an 11" beam (Motte & Andre 2001). To estimate the flux per resolution element, of ~1.4" for the proposed extended configuration observations, we assume that previously measured millimeter fluxes for our targets trace an optically thin, face-on disk with a surface density profile Sigma ~ r^-1 and a temperature profile T ~ r^-0.5. We use that F_nu ~ nu^(2+beta) at millimeter wavelengths, with a reasonable assumption of beta=0.7 (e.g. Rodmann et al. 2006, Ricci et al. 2010a,b), to estimate the 3 mm fluxes for targets without previous 3mm observations. We find that our targets will have peak brightnesses of 2-18 mJy/beam in a 1.4" beam. We will devote all four of our basebands to continuum observations, so we use 7.5 GHz of bandwidth to calculate sensitivity. To map the disk and extended envelop we must detect extended emission, which can be >10 times fainter than the peak brightness, at S/N > 2. We therefore request time on each source to achieve a peak S/N of 20.
Our observations in this band are continuum observations, so we request the default configuration for Band 3 continuum observations.

We request observations which cover a large range in the uv-plane so that we can produce maps of our targets which are sensitive to all of the relevant spatial scales for our targets, from the compact protoplanetary disks, to the large scale envelope structure. Protoplanetary disks typically have radii of < 300 AU (e.g. Furlan et al. 2008, Eisner 2012), or diameters <4.5" at 140 pc, so the requested resolution, of ~1.2" is essential for resolving these disks. Conversely, protostellar envelopes span large spatial scales on the order of a few thousand AU (e.g. Eisner 2012), so we want our observations to remain sensitive to spatial scales of 1000 - 3000 AU, or 7"-21" at 140 pc. We therefore list a largest angular scale of 21".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent studies suggest that protoplanetary disks around 1-5 Myr old pre-main sequence stars contain insufficient mass to form giant planets. This may be because by this stage much of the material in the disk has already grown into larger bodies, hiding the material from sight. To test this hypothesis, we propose to observe a diverse sample of protostars in Taurus younger than 1 Myr, whose disks are more likely to represent the initial mass budget of protoplanetary disks for forming planets. We will measure the mass of the disks around these protostars, constrain the maximum dust grain sizes in the disks, determine the geometry of the circumstellar material of these systems, and trace Keplerian rotation in the disks to measure the masses of the central protostars. By comparing the disk mass distribution and maximum dust grain sizes we derive for our sample with the existing 1-5 Myr old disk sample we will constrain the initial mass budget for forming planets in protoplanetary disks. We submitted a complementary proposal to repeat the experiment in Ophiuchus but kept the proposals separate as they explore different star forming regions and are each self contained.
